>So said Adam Jack on 2003-07-30 --------------------
>David wrote:
>
<sni=
p />
>I think test content dependency is wrong, but not what I am saying. 
=

A quick question: how do you have test dependency (in your sense) without =
test content dependency?

When I wrote a few examples, I found that when on=
e test depends on another (in your sense) there is duplication in the tests=
. At a minimum, the two tests make the same assertions.

>Either
>that, or =
you decouple yourself from everything you do, a purist goal of no
>real wor=
ld value. Code used code, that is a dependency.

You can have interface dep=
endency without implementation dependency. That is the decoupling mechanism=
 that tends to eliminate your test dependency issue.

<snip />
>This is all=
 about test content dependency -- side effects -- and I never
>meant that. =
Why get a fruit basket full of errors when fruit is bad? I was
>actually tr=
ying to reduce this mess of an output to "the *possible* root
>cause -- and=
 if nothing else, a place to start cleaning up".

The closer an object is t=
o the core of your application, the more important (I think) that failures =
in that object yell loudly and annoyingly. If your project has a big proble=
m with core classes failing on a regular basis, then maybe you have a proce=
ss/people problem, as opposed to a technical problem.

And lest you think I=
'm just deflecting, I'm not; I am sincerely trying to balance providing you=
 a solution with protecting the integrity of the core of JUnit.

Take care.=
